Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( LAW ) provides for designation of aerodromes by the Secretary of ORG . Where an aerodrome has been designated under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , the management of the aerodrome is required to consult organisations representing the interests of local people ( amongst others ) “ with respect to any matter concerning the management or administration of the aerodrome which affects their interest ... ” . ORG , published in DATE , state that the aim of consultation is “ to provide an effective forum for the discussion of all matters concerning the development or operation of the aerodrome , which have an impact on ... people living and working in the surrounding area ” , and to “ provid[e ] an opportunity to reconcile any differences of view that may arise , and [ to resolve ] difficulties through agreed voluntary action ” .
GPE aerodrome has been designated under LAW .
Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE LAW specific noise and/or use control measures .

Where an aerodrome has been specified under LAW , ORG is under a duty “ to have regard to the need to minimise so far as reasonably practicable - ( a ) any adverse effects on the environment , and ( b ) any disturbance to the public , from noise , vibration , atmospheric pollution or any other cause attributable to the use of aircraft for the purpose of civil aviation ” .
No aerodromes have been specified under LAW , although the Secretary of ORG has indicated to FAC that he is “ minded ” to specify it .

Where the Secretary of ORG has designated aerodromes under Section CARDINAL of LAW , the operator of the aerodrome is required to comply with requirements set out in the notice relating to noise and vibration connected with the taking off or landing of aircraft .
Only the major GPE airports ( FAC , GPE and GPE ) have been designated under LAW .
Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act permits the Secretary of ORG to make grants towards the cost of sound - proofing buildings near an aerodrome which has been designated under that section .
Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act excludes civil liability in trespass or nuisance in respect of flights of aircraft over property provided that the provisions of ORG have been complied with .

However , the prohibition in Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(e ) does not apply to aircraft which are taking off or landing ( Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) ) ; nor does it apply to practising approaches to landing at aerodromes ( Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) ) , as long as this is “ confined to the airspace customarily used by aircraft when landing or taking off in accordance with normal aviation practice at the aerodrome concerned ” ( Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ) .

The applicants complain under LAW that the noise caused by low flying aircraft including aerobatic activity , and helicopters , particularly training and maintenance , amounts to an interference with their right to respect for their private and family lives , and their homes , and that it can not be justified under LAW because ORG does not serve important national economic interests .

The applicants identify a legitimate aim which might be put forward in the case of a small , privately owned and operated aerodrome such as GPE , that of allowing “ innocent passage ” for aircraft across people ’s property . They contend that a balance should be struck between this and the interference with the rights guaranteed under LAW . They complain that the fact that a bar on actions for nuisance is imposed by LAW , and in particular by LAW ) thereof , that the bar applies regardless of the time of DATE or night when the noise is made , and regardless of the level or type of noise made , and that there are no effective alternative mechanisms in place to prevent noise nuisance , means that no balance has been struck , in breach of LAW .

The applicants further contend that the fact that the DATE LAW prevents them from bringing an action in nuisance , together with the fact that there is no other remedy available to them for breach of LAW , amounts to a violation of LAW .

Finally , the applicants contend that the level of noise generated by ORG has serious potential effects on the value of their properties . The PERSON contend that this is particularly so in their case , as the noise has become significantly worse since they purchased the house in DATE . The applicants contend that this amounts to a violation of LAW No . CARDINAL .
